awd_titl_txt: iDigFossils: Engaging K-12 Students in Integrated STEM via 3D Digitization, Printing and Exploration of Fossils
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will design and test a model for student engagement using paleontology as the disciplinary focus. Paleontology, or the scientific study of fossils, is a broad, interdisciplinary field that spans biology and geology.  Current paleontological research harnesses the resources provided by advanced technologies and modern statistics. The project will design, implement, and study a paleontology-focused and Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) aligned curriculum that infuses cutting-edge 3-D scanning and printing technologies in grades 6-12 Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). Authentic paleontological data, model-based reasoning, and socio-scientific problem solving will provide rich experiences integrating STEM disciplines in grades 6-12 and contribute to cultivating students' interest and identity in STEM. 

The project will design and implement a 3D technology-enhanced curriculum that infuses paleontology in K-12 as a truly integrated STEM science. The curriculum will enable students to use 3-D printing, computational modeling and other new technologies that will engage them in developing 21st century skills and introduce them to STEM careers. The project will introduce optimized research software for fossil interpretation and create apps for computational modeling using an existing, open source statistics environment.  The project will research effective conditions for scaffolding integrated STEM learning and the impact of the project on cultivating K-12 student interest and identity in STEM and related careers.  Project research and resources will be widely disseminated to researchers, students, teachers, and informal educators. This project is funded by the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program that supports projects that build understandings of best practices, program elements, contexts and processes contributing to engaging students in learning and developing interest in STEM, information and communications technology (ICT), computer science, and related STEM content and careers.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
Project iDigFossils was funded to expand and extend our understanding of integrated Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) learning and explore the potential benefits and challenges associated with it.

iDigFossils is a model for integrating all four STEM domains, plus literacy and the arts, in K-12 education using 3D scanning and printing technologies that are increasingly finding their way into K-12 schools. More important, iDigFossils is a national network of K-12 teachers, scientists, researchers, and, of course, students interested in paleontology, geology, and biology and their relationships with other STEM fields such as computer science, data visualization, computational modeling, and scientific illustration.

The outcomes of our iDigFossils research and development include a novel curricular model for integrating STEM disciplines in K-12 education, lessons and activities, professional development materials for K-12 teachers, scientific and educational publications and presentations, as well as novel interactive 3D visualization tools and computational modeling applications to engage students in hands-on minds-on learning. These resources organically integrate STEM and address the three dimensions of the K-12 science education framework ? a) science and engineering practices, b) crosscutting concepts, and c) core ideas. 

While solving paleontology-focused iDigFossils problems, K-12 students 3D scan, 3D print, and explore fossils, and develop deep understandings of evolution, biodiversity, and climate change. The interactive 3D visualization tools and computational modeling apps, as well as lesson plans, professional development materials, and 3D models have been made available to any teacher implementing 3D technologies in the classroom, or a parent or guardian interested in engaging their child in learning STEM via fossil exploration, 3D scanning and/or 3D printing. 

Our research, development, and education activities have produced new practical knowledge on the effective strategies and conditions for supporting equitable and engaged participation in integrated STEM to cultivate K-12 students? interest and identity in STEM. For example, our national study with 192 elementary students, 847 middle school students, and 462 high school students demonstrated that students? engagement in iDigFossils activities and teachers? ability to integrate STEM disciplines were important predictors of students? interest in STEM careers. Teachers? 3D printing integration level, STEM integration level, pedagogical beliefs, value beliefs, and self-efficacy beliefs in the use of 3D printing in the classroom predicted students? STEM motivation, namely science motivation, technology and engineering motivation, and math motivation respectively while controlling for student gender and students? pretest scores.

We have created and tested dozens of lesson plans for elementary, middle and high school classrooms that leverage 3D scanning, 3D printing and the study of fossils to improve students? learning and motivation outcomes. We have also designed a number of web-based and mobile friendly apps that can be used to increase student engagement and interest in STEM:

App 1: Measure the length of Titanoboa: https://wood- idigfossils.shinyapps.io/snake_length/  

App 2: How big was Megalodon? https://wood-idigfossils.shinyapps.io/Megalodon 

App 3: Fossil whale total body length: https://wood- idigfossils.shinyapps.io/fossil_whale_tbl/ 

pp 4: Mammal diet energy: https://wood- idigfossils.shinyapps.io/mammal_diet_energy/

Our project is expanding the theory and practice of integrating STEM disciplines in K-12 education via a model of student engagement that uses 3D scanning and printing technologies in the context of paleontology, an unexplored pathway to K-12 STEM education. We look forward to continuing our partnerships with K-12 teachers, parents, colleges, STEM clubs and summer programs to engage our youth in the exploration of STEM as it relates to the key issues our society faces in the 21st century. 


Last Modified: 03/29/2022
Modified by: Pasha Antonenko
